query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Contra miglior voler voler mal pugna; 2 onde contra ’l piacer mio, per piacerli, 3 trassi de l’acqua non sazia la spugna.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Against a better will, an evil will struggles; 2 therefore against my own pleasure, to please him, 3 I drew from the water the sponge not yet satisfied.
**Cornish:**
1 Contra gweller voel voel drok a wra junya; 2 rag rag contra ow pleser, rag plesya ef, 3 my a wra trehya a'n dowr an spunj nyns sodhis.

**English:**
10 Accursed be you, ancient she-wolf, 11 who more than all other beasts are ravenous 12 for your insatiable hunger!
13 O heavens, in whose revolutions it seems to be believed 14 that the conditions down here change, 15 when will he come for whom this she-wolf will depart?
16 We were walking with slow and weary steps, 17 and I was paying attention to the shades, whom I heard 18 weeping and lamenting pitifully;
19 and by chance I heard "Sweet Mary!" 20 being called out before us in the weeping 21 as a woman does when she is in labor;
22 and then: "You were so poor, 23 as can be seen from that inn 24 where you gave birth to your holy burden."
**Cornish:**
10 Malledhys vy, an gwrach koth, 11 moy es oll an bestes erel vyth preda 12 rag an agas heb fin kewas dowr!
13 O nef, yn aga drohevel syw parsys creda 14 an kechyow a-woles y'n treylya yma, 15 pyw vyth dhevedh rag an onan ma ythoma?
16 Ni a veu kerdhes gans passys lent ha skars, 17 ha my a veu prederus orth an skewys, aga klevyas 18 ow poes yn fethys ow kewyna ha ow lagna;
19 ha rag gwella'th y klevyas "Dowr Vari!" 20 owth dhevedhes ragdhon ni yn an kewyna 21 dell yw gwres gwragh pan yw yn parturi.
22 Ha owth sevel: "Bogh vythsa kemmys, 23 dell yw gweles rag an osbys honan 24 le mayth vyth sponyes an agas purtas sans."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Seguentemente intesi: «O buon Fabrizio, 26 con povertà volesti anzi virtute 27 che gran ricchezza posseder con vizio».
query.result:
**English:**
25 Then I heard: "O good Fabricius, 26 with poverty you preferred virtue 27 to possessing great wealth with vice."
**Cornish:**
25 Wosa henna klevyas: "O Fabricius da, 26 gans boghder vyth owth karas rag virtu 27 es possessa golud bras gans vyth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Queste parole m’eran sì piaciute, 29 ch’io mi trassi oltre per aver contezza 30 di quello spirto onde parean venute.
query.result:
**English:**
28 These words were so pleasing to me, 29 that I moved forward to learn more 30 about the spirit from whom they seemed to come.
**Cornish:**
28 An gerow-ma na veu kemmys owth karas, 29 henna owth omdhyskynas rag aga konta 30 a'gan sperys owth paryas owth dos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Esso parlava ancor de la larghezza 32 che fece Niccolò a le pulcelle, 33 per condurre ad onor lor giovinezza.
query.result:
**English:**
31 He was still speaking of the generosity 32 that Nicholas showed to the young women, 33 in order to lead their youth to honor.
**Cornish:**
31 Ev a veu owth kewsel a-dro dhe'gan ledra 32 aga wrug Nikola dhe'gan yowynkyon, 33 rag aga gorra aga yowynkder dhe onor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 «O anima che tanto ben favelle, 35 dimmi chi fosti», dissi, «e perché sola 36 tu queste degne lode rinovelle.
query.result:
**English:**
34 "O soul who speaks so well, 35 tell me who you were," I said, "and why you alone 36 renew these worthy praises.
**Cornish:**
34 "O eneval owth kewsel kemmys da, 35 dywedh vyth pyw vythsa," me a leveris, "ha hwyrrag vyth onan 36 owth adnowa an molenow-ma owth karas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Non fia sanza mercé la tua parola, 38 s’io ritorno a compiér lo cammin corto 39 di quella vita ch’al termine vola».
query.result:
**English:**
37 Your words will not be without reward, 38 if I return to complete the short journey 39 of that life which is flying towards its end.
**Cornish:**
37 Na vyth heb marsowth an gerow-ma, 38 mar dyvydh vyth dhe'gan gorra an fordh byghan 39 a'gan bywder owth hedha dhe'gan termen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Ed elli: «Io ti dirò, non per conforto 41 ch’io attenda di là, ma perché tanta 42 grazia in te luce prima che sie morto.
query.result:
**English:**
40 And he: "I will tell you, not for any comfort 41 that I expect from there, but because so much 42 grace shines in you before you are dead.
**Cornish:**
40 Ha henna: "Vy a leverow dhys, na rag marsowth 41 owth attendaf vyth a-dhia, mes rag kemmys 42 gras owth skler yn-tas kyns vyth marow."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Io fui radice de la mala pianta 44 che la terra cristiana tutta aduggia, 45 sì che buon frutto rado se ne schianta.
query.result:
**English:**
43 I was the root of the evil plant 44 that overshadows all of Christendom, 45 so that good fruit is rarely harvested from it.
**Cornish:**
43 Vy veu gwreydh a'gan plann drog 44 owth aduj oll an norvys kristyon, 45 henna owth skila kemmys frooth da a-dhiworth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Ma se Doagio, Lilla, Guanto e Bruggia 47 potesser, tosto ne saria vendetta; 48 e io la cheggio a lui che tutto giuggia.
query.result:
**English:**
46 But if Douai, Lille, Ghent and Bruges 47 could, vengeance would soon be taken; 48 and I ask it of Him who judges all.
**Cornish:**
46 Mes mar Doagio, Lilla, Gwans ha Bruggia 47 a gallos, byth vyth venjans a-dhia; 48 ha vy a'y geyj dhe'gan owth jugj oll.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Chiamato fui di là Ugo Ciappetta; 50 di me son nati i Filippi e i Luigi 51 per cui novellamente è Francia retta.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I was called Hugh Capet down there; 50 from me were born the Philips and the Louises 51 by whom France is now ruled.
**Cornish:**
49 Vy veu galwes a-dhia Hugo Kapet; 50 a vyth veu genys an Filippi ha an Lowisi 51 rag aga yw Frans rettys yn-tas owth skon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Figliuol fu’ io d’un beccaio di Parigi: 53 quando li regi antichi venner meno 54 tutti, fuor ch’un renduto in panni bigi,
55 trova’mi stretto ne le mani il freno 56 del governo del regno, e tanta possa 57 di nuovo acquisto, e sì d’amici pieno,
58 ch’a la corona vedova promossa 59 la testa di mio figlio fu, dal quale 60 cominciar di costor le sacrate ossa.
query.error:
index: 0
content {
  parts {
    text: "**English:**

52 Son of a butcher of Paris was I:
53 when the ancient kings all came to an end,
54 except for one clad in humble gray,

55 I found the reins of government of the kingdom
56 tightly held in my hands, and such great power
57 newly acquired, and so full of friends,

58 that the widowed crown was raised
59 upon the head of my son, from whom
60 began the sacred bones of these men.

**Cornish:**

52 Mab o gesyk a Baris oen:
53 pan veu an reow koth henna oll
54 marnas onan gwiskes yn glas,

55 kavos yn fast yn y dhewlagas
56 lywydh an wlas, ha gallos bras
57 nowydh, ha leun a vynoryon,

58 bys dhe'n kurun weddw dhe'n golgh
59 pen y vab, dhyworth pyth
60 dallethaskorrasowennek."
  }
  role: "model"
}

query.result:
**English:**
52 Son of a butcher of Paris was I: 53 when the ancient kings all came to an end, 54 except for one clad in humble gray,
55 I found the reins of government of the kingdom 56 tightly held in my hands, and such great power 57 newly acquired, and so full of friends,
58 that the widowed crown was raised 59 upon the head of my son, from whom 60 began the sacred bones of these men.
**Cornish:**
52 Mab o gesyk a Baris oen: 53 pan veu an reow koth henna oll 54 marnas onan gwiskes yn glas,
55 kavos yn fast yn y dhewlagas 56 lywydh an wlas, ha gallos bras 57 nowydh, ha leun a vynoryon,
58 bys dhe'n kurun weddw dhe'n golgh 59 pen y vab, dhyworth pyth 60 dallethaskorrasowennek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Mentre che la gran dota provenzale 62 al sangue mio non tolse la vergogna, 63 poco valea, ma pur non facea male.
query.result:
**English:**
61 While the great dowry from Provence 62 did not remove the shame from my bloodline, 63 it was worth little, but still did no harm.
**Cornish:**
61 Panvrea an brassa dowransoweth 62 dhe'm gwaedh na gavas an wonn, 63 byghan o prys, mes na wrug drok.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Lì cominciò con forza e con menzogna 65 la sua rapina; e poscia, per ammenda, 66 Pontì e Normandia prese e Guascogna.
query.result:
**English:**
64 There he began with force and with deceit 65 his plundering; and afterwards, as amends, 66 he seized Ponthieu and Normandy and Gascony.
**Cornish:**
64 Eno deuth ha bos ha goweth 65 y dha ladronieth; ha wosa, rag amendys, 66 Pontì ha Normandi ha Gwaskon a gemeras.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Carlo venne in Italia e, per ammenda, 68 vittima fé di Curradino; e poi 69 ripinse al ciel Tommaso, per ammenda.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Charles came to Italy and, as amends, 68 made Conradin his victim; and then 69 he sent Thomas back to heaven, as amends.
**Cornish:**
67 Charles a dheuth dhe Italli, ha, rag amendys, 68 oberas vyctim a Gurradino; ha wosa 69 ev a dhaskyrghas Thomas dhe'n nef, rag amendys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Tempo vegg’ io, non molto dopo ancoi, 71 che tragge un altro Carlo fuor di Francia, 72 per far conoscer meglio e sé e ’ suoi.
query.result:
**English:**
70 I see a time, not long from now, 71 when another Charles comes out of France, 72 to make himself and his followers better known.
**Cornish:**
70 Amser a welaf, nyns yw bell ow pella, 71 pan vo Charles aral dhe Frànk, 72 rag gul wel dhe dhiskwedhes ef ha'y dus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Sanz’ arme n’esce e solo con la lancia 74 con la qual giostrò Giuda, e quella ponta 75 sì, ch’a Fiorenza fa scoppiar la pancia.
query.result:
**English:**
73 He goes forth unarmed and only with the lance 74 with which Judas jousted, and he thrusts it so 75 that he makes Florence burst open at the belly.
**Cornish:**
73 Heb arm n’eus ha onan gans an lans 74 gans pan jotras Judas, ha henna a ponta 75 mar, bys dhe Fiorenza dhe dhalleth an kodha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Quindi non terra, ma peccato e onta 77 guadagnerà, per sé tanto più grave, 78 quanto più lieve simil danno conta.
query.result:
**English:**
76 From this he will gain not land, but sin and shame, 77 which will be all the more serious for him 78 since he counts such harm as slight.
**Cornish:**
76 Wosa henna nyns yw tir, mes pechodh ha gwonn, 77 a dheth bys moyha, rag ef moy ages, 78 vel drok mar byghan yw an drok henna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 L’altro, che già uscì preso di nave, 80 veggio vender sua figlia e patteggiarne 81 come fanno i corsar de l’altre schiave.
query.result:
**English:**
79 The other, who once escaped by ship, 80 I see selling his daughter and bargaining for her 81 as pirates do with their other slaves.
**Cornish:**
79 Aral, a wrug onanweth dhe'n les, 80 a welaf ow prenna y vrec’h ha ober marchand 81 mar corsars a wra ober gans aga sklavow erel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 O avarizia, che puoi tu più farne, 83 poscia c’ha’ il mio sangue a te sì tratto, 84 che non si cura de la propria carne?
85 Perché men paia il mal futuro e ’l fatto, 86 veggio in Alagna intrar lo fiordaliso, 87 e nel vicario suo Cristo esser catto.
query.result:
**English:**
82 O avarice, what more can you do to us, 83 since you have drawn my blood to you so much 84 that it cares nothing for its own flesh?
85 So that the evil to come and the evil done may seem less to me, 86 I see the fleur-de-lis enter Anagni 87 and Christ being taken prisoner in his vicar.
**Cornish:**
82 O avaris, pyth a alli thu moy oberi, 83 wosa t’eus ow tynna’m gwaedh dhe’th bys mar, 84 na wra ges kar dhe'y honen korf?
85 Rag an drok dhe dhesi ha’n drok wruthyl, 86 a welaf an flour-de-lis dhe vos dhe Alagna, 87 ha Krist dhe vos kemerys y’n y vycari.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Veggiolo un’altra volta esser deriso; 89 veggio rinovellar l’aceto e ’l fiele, 90 e tra vivi ladroni esser anciso.
query.result:
**English:**
88 I see him mocked a second time; 89 I see the vinegar and the gall renewed, 90 and him put to death among living thieves.
**Cornish:**
88 A welaf ef dhe vos skofys aral; 89 a welaf an vineger ha’n fiel dhe vos nowydh, 90 ha ef dhe vos ladhes ynter ladrons byw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Veggio il novo Pilato sì crudele, 92 che ciò nol sazia, ma sanza decreto 93 portar nel Tempio le cupide vele.
query.result:
**English:**
91 I see the new Pilate so cruel, 92 that this does not satisfy him, but without decree 93 he carries the greedy sails into the Temple.**Cornish:**
91 Yth gwelyn an Pilat nowydh kemmys krueel, 92 na wra dhegees henna, mes heb dekret 93 ev a dheuth an Tempyl an veyl kyndek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 O Segnor mio, quando sarò io lieto 95 a veder la vendetta che, nascosa, 96 fa dolce l’ira tua nel tuo secreto?
97 Ciò ch’io dicea di quell’ unica sposa 98 de lo Spirito Santo e che ti fece 99 verso me volger per alcuna chiosa,
100 tanto è risposto a tutte nostre prece 101 quanto ’l dì dura; ma com’ el s’annotta, 102 contrario suon prendemo in quella vece.
query.result:
**English:**
94 O my Lord, when will I be joyful 95 to see the vengeance that, hidden, 96 makes your wrath sweet in your secret?
97 What I said about that unique bride 98 of the Holy Spirit and who made you 99 turn to me for some explanation,
100 is answered to all our prayers 101 as long as the day lasts; but when night falls, 102 we take the opposite meaning instead.**Cornish:**
94 O fy Arloedh, peves vythaf vy leun? 95 Rag gweles an venjans, kudyn, 96 a wra dhegees dowr dhe wrag yn dhy gudyn?
97 An peth ow leveris a-dro dhe'n unnik brath 98 a'n Spyrys Sans ha'gas ow th'ober 99 dhe'm trohevel rag nebes omdhiskwedhes,
100 yw henwys dhe bub oll agan pednow 101 kyns trwa an jydh; mes pan vo nos, 102 nyns yw an keth an keverel a-dro dhe'n keth.

**English:**
103 We repeated the fate of Pygmalion, 104 whom his greed for gold made a traitor, thief and murderer;
106 and the misery of the miserly Midas, 107 who followed his greedy request, 108 for which it is always right to laugh.**Cornish:**
103 Ny a leveris Pigmalion ollta, 104 neb traytour ha lader ha parecida 105 a wrug y volonteth dhe'n our gwyls.
106 Ha truen Mida an avar, 107 a sewys y dhimand gordh, 108 rag an peth ma wra dhegees dhe'n hwerthin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Del folle Acàn ciascun poi si ricorda, 110 come furò le spoglie, sì che l’ira 111 di Iosüè qui par ch’ancor lo morda.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Everyone then remembers the foolish Achan, 110 how he stole the spoils, so that the wrath 111 of Joshua here seems to still bite him.**Cornish:**
109 A-dro dhe'n fol Acàn pub onan a'n kov, 110 pena wra y spoyl, lemmyn an wragh 111 a Josué yma a wra dhegees dhe'n bova.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Talor parla l’uno alto e l’altro basso, 119 secondo l’affezion ch’ad ir ci sprona 120 ora a maggiore e ora a minor passo:
121 però al ben che ’l dì ci si ragiona, 122 dianzi non era io sol; ma qui da presso 123 non alzava la voce altra persona».
query.result:
**English:**
118 Sometimes one speaks loudly and the other softly, 119 according to the passion that spurs us to anger, 120 now at a faster and now at a slower pace:
121 therefore, as for the good that we talk about during the day, 122 earlier I was not alone; but here nearby 123 no other person raised their voice.**Cornish:**
118 Unyth a lever an eyl ughel ha'n eyl isel, 119 herwydh an affecshon a spron ny dhe wrag 120 unwaith dhe vos ha dhe vos dhe'n isel pass:
121 Rag dhe'n da a leverir ny dhe jydh, 122 kyns henna nyns oen omma; mes yma ogas 123 nyns oedh neb aral a leveris y leus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Noi eravam partiti già da esso, 125 e brigavam di soverchiar la strada 126 tanto quanto al poder n’era permesso,
127 quand’ io senti’, come cosa che cada, 128 tremar lo monte; onde mi prese un gelo 129 qual prender suol colui ch’a morte vada.
query.result:
**English:**
124 We had already left him, 125 and we were striving to cover as much ground 126 as we were allowed to,
127 when I heard, like something falling, 128 the mountain tremble; whereupon a chill seized me 129 such as seizes one who is going to his death.**Cornish:**
124 Ny oen parti ow tos owth, 125 ha ny oen omstrivya rag gorhelhe an fordh 126 kyns oedh gallos dhe'n gallu,
127 pan glewas, kepar peth a wra yn kodha, 128 an menydh yn kryjya; lemmyn y kemeras 129 kepar neb a wra dhe'n mernans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Certo non si scoteo sì forte Delo, 131 pria che Latona in lei facesse ’l nido 132 a parturir li due occhi del cielo.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Surely Delos did not shake so violently, 131 before Latona made her nest there 132 to give birth to the two eyes of heaven.**Cornish:**
130 Sygur na wra Delo yn kryjya kemmys kalet, 131 kyns Latona ynti a wrug an neyth 132 rag genys an dhewlagas a'n nef.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Poi cominciò da tutte parti un grido 134 tal, che ’l maestro inverso me si feo, 135 dicendo: «Non dubbiar, mentr’ io ti guido».
query.result:
**English:**
133 Then from all sides a cry began, 134 such that the master turned to me, 135 saying: “Do not fear, while I am guiding you”.**Cornish:**
133 Wosa henna yth kovyas ow tos pub tu, 134 lemmyn an mester dhe'm tu a wra, 135 ow leverel: “Na wra ofn, kyns owth owth a'n ledyas”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 ‘Glorïa in excelsis’ tutti ‘Deo’ 137 dicean, per quel ch’io da’ vicin compresi, 138 onde intender lo grido si poteo.
query.result:
**English:**
136 ‘Gloria in excelsis’ everyone said ‘Deo’, 137 from what I understood from those nearby, 138 whence the cry could be understood.**Cornish:**
136 ‘Glorïa in excelsis’ pub ‘Deo’ 137 a leveris, rag an peth ow komprehendyas ow tos, 138 lemmyn an leverel a alla.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 No’ istavamo immobili e sospesi 140 come i pastor che prima udir quel canto, 141 fin che ’l tremar cessò ed el compiési.
query.result:
**English:**
139 We stood there, motionless and suspended, 140 like shepherds who first hear that song, 141 until the trembling ceased and we moved on.
**Cornish:**
139 Nyns omov ni sevel ha golowes, 140 kepar an bewon a glewas an gana, 141 bys na lemynas an kryjy ha mos mos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 Poi ripigliammo nostro cammin santo, 143 guardando l’ombre che giacean per terra, 144 tornate già in su l’usato pianto.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Then we resumed our holy journey, 143 looking at the shadows that lay on the ground, 144 now returned to their accustomed weeping.
**Cornish:**
142 Wosa henna nyns kemer an fordh sans, 143 ow tos ow sel an skevens ow tos war an nor, 144 ow tos dyworth dhe'n gwella gwynn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 Nulla ignoranza mai con tanta guerra 146 mi fé desideroso di sapere, 147 se la memoria mia in ciò non erra,
148 quanta pareami allor, pensando, avere; 149 né per la fretta dimandare er’ oso, 150 né per me lì potea cosa vedere:
151 così m’andava timido e pensoso.
query.result:
**English:**
145 Never did ignorance wage such war against me 146 with such a desire to know, 147 if my memory does not err in this,
148 as it seemed to me then, as I thought about it; 149 but I did not dare to ask, because of my haste, 150 nor could I see anything there for myself:
151 thus I went on, timid and thoughtful.
**Cornish:**
145 Nyns esa anvosoweth bythkweth par bell, 146 ow tos ow hwilli orth ydhyn, 147 mar nyns yw ow kov sodho,
148 kepar hag yth esa dhe'm, ow tos owthynkya; 149 mes nyns esa owth ow hwyllsa orth gorra, 150 na orth ydhyn ow tos ow hwel orth hemma:
151 kepar henna ow tos ow mos, owth ow kov sodho ha owth owthynkya.
